After reading some of the comments, I was curious to find answers to some of the questions they generated. FYI:

Petrichor, the scent of rain on fresh earth, comes from geosmin, a molecule produced by the Streptomyces bacteria. Present in most healthy soils, these bacteria are also used to create commercial antibiotics and are partly responsible for coloring beets. Geosmin is captured to sell as a scent called "matti ka attar" in Uttar Pradesh, India. (Somebody mentioned a YouTube video showing the traditional process.)

My source was a BBC News article by Science reporter Mary Halton, published on July 27, 2018.

Your explanation of why palladium on carbon is kinda wrong. I'm sure you know this by now bit it is entirely because of the astronomical expense of palladium. Normally if you wanted more surface area you would add more fine metal powder - but it is FAR cheaper to deposit the palladium on carbon than to buy more palladium. And the deposition process isnt exactly that cheap. Exactly the same reason the same thing is done for vehicle catalytic converters, but the rhodium and palladium in those can still be hundreds of dollars - the current price of palladium is US$83 a gram, rhodium is US$650 a gram atm.

Also, based on my own experience and what other perfumers said, "just adding enough alcohol to dissolve the raspberry ketone" is WAY too strong for a reasonable perfume or food flavoring. Though it doesn't smell bad, spraying RK solution of such strength on your skin will make you smell like RK for probably 1-2 weeks despite showering twice a day, probably. I've got a 30-gram bag of RK from Perfumer's Apprentice for my own perfumery pleasure; I have to quadruple-bag it (and put it in a freezer) to control its scent from leaking out excessively. RK is not something so pungent to immediately tell you how strong it is; in fact it smells mild even when concentrated. However, it has an extremely low odor threshold AND is tremendously tenacious – in line with many musk odorants! Even in a “raspberry accord” RK is seldom used in more than 10%; 1.5-3% is more typical. In a finished perfume the level of RK is usually much lower. It is added in trace amounts to give fruity undertones to floral notes and is an excellent fixative for (usually short-lived) fruity notes.

When you're recrystallizing something, never heat it above its melting point, or it will always oil out (because then it comes out as a liquid initially, and then pulls in all the impurities instead of leaving them in solution).  You're better off heating it in water to below the melting point, adding alcohol until everything just dissolves, and then cooling.  Or switching to ethyl acetate/hexanes.

TLC should not be taken quantitiavely as different compounds stain at different intensities (also depends on the stain). For intance, if you work with the trityl (and it's derivatives such as DMTr) protecting group, it is a 'super-stainer'. I.e. Even tiny amounts of it will stain with ridiculously high intensities - this is true for virtually any stain with trityl.
So do not presume TLC to be quantitative as it may fool you into thinking your produuct is more/less pure than you think.

That was friggin' awesome, great work! I'm a hobbyist perfumer myself, so I thought it was pretty cool to see how some of my favorite materials are made.
If you want to want to make that into a more robust raspberry smell, I would suggest adding small amounts of linalool, limonene, and beta-pinene. Ethyl 6-acetyloxyhexanoate (Berryflor) can also go a long way in bringing out the fresh raspberry smell. Use small amounts at low dilution (1-10% is pretty standard. I used to work in a laboratory in a brewery and, at first, was stunned by the sheer number of compounds present in beer that contribute to it's flavour.  It's literally hundreds of them.  More surprising was that beer could taste like anything from lager, stout, cider, wine or even vinegar just dependent on the variability of this rich cocktail of aromas present.  A lot of these products were created by the yeast.  My job was to cultivate the yeast strains we used to ensure that we were producing the flavours expected by our customers and also avoiding the less desirable by products (some of which can actually be hazardous to the health).  And one of the biggest surprises was, that the amount of Alcohol present in the final product had very little significance in the flavour of the product.  Even though, it was by far, more abundant than any of the other compounds that produced the actual flavour.  So, as you say, just taking a single compound present in an aroma, is never going to fool the palate that it's anything like the real thing.

For purification of aldehydes or ketones, it's hard to beat the sodium bisulfite adduct method.  Simply add the ketone in ethanol to an aqueous solution of sodium bisulfite.  A crystalline precipitate of ketone/bisulfite adduct will form that can be filtered or decanted off.  The purified ketone can be recovered by adding the adduct to a dilute NaOH solution.  The ketone will form an insoluble phase and can be recovered using a separatory funnel.  You can practice this technique using acetone or MEK as your starting material.  The adduct will be a white powder that when added to dilute NaOH will again smell like the starting ketone.

Hi! Your low yield was probably due to the aldolic condensation you did. Acid alpha-hydrogens from acetone (and ketones in general) do not usually undergo acid-base reactions with OH-, unless you're working with dicarbonyllic compounds (such as mallonic ester). It is common to deprotonize alpha-ketone hydrogens with LDA. One might argue that since the product is generally more stable, being a alpha-beta insaturated carbonyl compound, the reaction may undergo with OH- as the basic agent, nevertheless it has also been observed that alpha hydrogens specifically from acetone do not react even with such a strong base as LDA (and I honestly do not know why this happens). To have a greater yield in the aldolic condensation shown here, it would be needed to synthetize a reactive intermediate known as enamine, reacting acetone with an amine, usually pyrrolidine. Of course this makes the synthesis longer and more complex. Hope it helps you!

You messed up at the aldol condensation. If you use an excess of acetone in the presence of NaOH, you get a multitude of reactions of acetone to mesityl oxide and isophrone as well as having excess acetone react with your wanted product (or any of the acetone condensation products reacting with your aldehyde). Aldol-type reactions with ketones that have protons on both sides are notoriously annoying and need very careful stochiometric control. There's also the competing Cannizarro reaction but that's rather slow compared to the aldol.

My thoughts on why the product might not be completely pure.


I think there may have been some non selectivity in the catalysis, as from my experience (I'm a PhD student in hetro catalysis) Pd tends to have a sweet spot in the reaction cycle where it will first selectively hydrogenate the double bond, as this is a much less stable bond. After which it will move onto the ketone group, turning it to an alcohol or removing the oxide all together. Giving two overlapping curves with a maximum of ideal product then fading to form unwanted by products.


To avoid this try a poisoned palladium or Raney nickel catalyst as from what I've seen they offer a greater region where the ketone is maintained but the alkene is hydrogenated. Or using a controlled molar ratio of reducing agent to target the sweet spot.


Something like GCMS or LCMS would be a great way to monitor this as the alcohol and aldehyde tend co-elute (or just be difficult to resolve from one and other) and MS can differentiate them. Even though these techniques are damn expensive in a private setting.

Try to make thioacetone. Here is what wikipedia has to say about it:
Thioacetone has an intensely foul odor. Like many low molecular weight organosulfur compounds, the smell is potent and can be detected even when highly diluted.[6] In 1889, an attempt to distill the chemical in the German city of Freiburg was followed by cases of vomiting, nausea and unconsciousness in an area with a radius of 0.75 kilometres (0.47 mi) around the laboratory due to the smell.[7] British chemists at the Whitehall Soap Works in Leeds noted in an 1890 report that dilution seemed to make the smell worse and described the smell as "fearful".[8] Thioacetone is considered a dangerous chemical due to its extremely foul odor and ability to render people unconscious, induce vomiting, and be detected over long distances.

So some notes on organic products:
-The catalyst might be holding onto large amounts of the product. High surface area catalysts, like powdered carbon, need to be rinsed with solvent.

-Ketones have the ability to form hemiacetals, and a weird condensation product. Even if the ketone isn't soluble in water, adding water might reverse the condensation product.... unless i'm thinking backwards again and it makes the product more of a problem...

- finally, and more as a thing with the raspberry ketone: the smell might be pH dependent. Not that it will change scent if you change the pH, but adjusting the pH might free up more of the compound to evaporate off into the air. You might try adding a small amount of ammonia or a small amount of vinegar to perfume to bring out the raspberry smell. (a very small amount)

I would like to ask you to do a video about glycosides and in particular, the glycoside Wisterin. It is a toxic chemical found in the common flowering plant Wisteria. This chemical is toxic to humans and various types of animals. It is found in almost all parts of the plant. It is part of the Pea family of plants.

The toxin from Oleander, Oleandrin, is also a glycoside I have discovered. Stronger than Wisterin.

Hello NR, I would like to make an investigation request.

This is not related to the red raspberry chem, but related to bird chem.

Many bird owners such as myself have noticed what we call the "wet bird" smell.
It seems that when water is added to a bird, there is a aromatic change (not offensive per say, bit noticeable and very distinct).
It lasts only as long as the bird is wet.

Now, I know that birds excrete their own kind kind of "talcum powder" that they use to lubricate their wings so that they slide smoothly with less less friction, and I suspect that it is this that is reacting with the water. But this is only my guess.

Might be worth an investigation, and I'm sure bird owners would find it interesting.

I wish I would have seen this yesterday. My students just got done running an aldol condensation and hydrogenation of their own, but they're turning in their lab reports tomorrow.

I must say that this synthesis path, especially the aldol reaction is a pretty messy reaction and creates probably dozens of minor self-condensation products from acetone. These are also fun to explore, because apparently mesityl oxide smells like honey, phorone smells like geraniums and isophorone like peppermint (but it's carcinogenic though...). Not sure about another route you can try with the equipment and chemicals you have in hand though. If you want to make terrible smelling compounds: isocyanides. Not as toxic as you might expect from the name luckily, but from my own experience, these compounds are the worst. I think you should try using iso propyl alcohol for recrystalization. It has several benefits. IPA is a quite poor solvent for most compounds, so that in a recrystalization you will be able to get most of your product out of solution. It also has a quite high boiling point which means you will have a greater difference between hot and cold (compared to ethanol). There is also a greater chance that your impurity will be soluble in IPA than in water (if it is a tar-like polymer). And finally, crystals from IPA behave nicer than crystals from water - for example they don't stick so much to the sides of your glassware.

Hydrogen is somewhat scary to work with. At lab we were teached to always at least double flush with good flow using argon (which is great because it is heavier than air). We also always used doubled balloons. In case one layer breaks you still have the hydrogen enclosed in a backup layer. Yes, we took the amount needed from a canister into a doubled balloon. (That prevents any large leaks from a canister).
I'm so suprised to see you've not invested on a canister of nitrogen yet. Those should be pretty cheap.
In amateur lab you are usually not afraid of side reactions due to air. In pro lab we did almost all reactions under argon just in case. In small scale (like milligrams) protective gas can be essential to prevent side reactions. That scale is out of amateur labs though, because you have hardly any means to analyze results unlike in pro lab with all the bells and whistles like NMR that can analyze easily sub milligram scale.

For anyone curious, Celite is a special kind of sand called diatomaceous earth, which is actually sedimentary layers of fossils of microscopic sea organisms that settled and then were thrust above sea level by tectonic movement. It's useful for filtration because you're basically running material through microscopic skeletons. One of the larger deposits of the stuff is near Lompoc, CA, where I grew up, and where my grandfather worked on the stuff as a chemical engineer for many years.

Generally, you should co-spot your TLCs. I.e. (starting material) (sm + product) (product) . This is because there are differences in the elution rate across the width of the plate.

Additionally, you should generally agitate during crystallization. This gives more consistent crystal size and (somewhat unintuitively) better purity. It seems like the big crystals will be more pure, but the problem with crystals that grow on the bottom is they meld together and trap impurities. When crystals are stirred gently enough to suspend them but not too aggressively, they are much less likely to entrain junk.

Also, pro tip for crystalizations: If you have the time, slow it down as much as you can. Instead of leaving the container on a counter to cool down put some sort of insulation around it and when it gets to room temperature put it into the freezer (freezer can be done without the insulation). The slower the crystallization is the more pure it will be, and the colder you get it the more you will take out of solution.

In particular, this is a Claisen-Schmidt condensation due to the aldehyde being aromatic. I've usually had pretty good results with them being near quantitative; My first though is potentially the amount of catalyst being used. On a scale of about a gram of starting material, I've typically used about 0.5 mL of 3M NaOH. Maybe the quantity being used here results in the formation of the enolate of the product rather than just acetone.
